titleInfo.title: Log-Profile Analysis of the near-Surface Layer and Air-Sea Turbulent Fluxes in Hurricanes Using Dropsondes

name.namePart: Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science

mods:mods.abstract: Vertical profiles of wind, potential temperature, and humidity within hurricanes are shown to exhibit approximately log-linear behavior within the near-surface layer and can therefore be used to estimate log-profile parameters in such an environment. We analyze data collected from individual dropsondes in an attempt to better understand the near-surface values of wind, potential temperature, and humidity. This analysis has the advantage of simultaneously fitting all three non-neutral profiles via a Python-based minimization code. Several of these fitting parameters can be combined to estimate surface fluxes of momentum, sensible heat, and latent heat within tropical cyclones. Several strengths and weaknesses of this method will be discussed. Vertical offsets of the profiles have been observed, which could be due to waves or sea spray pushing them upward, or due to an error in the recorded surface level from the dropsonde. Our methodology accounts for these offsets through a displacement height for each profile. While still providing a very good fit to the observations, the log-profile parameters can be sensitive to displacement height error in a manner that impacts our estimation of fluxes. In addition, some assumptions are made regarding surface values for each of the profiles. In terms of a fit to the profiles, the errors in surface values are largely compensated for by the errors in roughness length and have no impact on the friction velocity (or similar terms) and fluxes. The errors in roughness length are exponentially related to the errors in the surface values, which in some cases results in extremely large roughness lengths. Despite the weaknesses, our methods are able to produce near-surface estimates and flux estimates within a certain range of uncertainty that is determined from the observed profiles. These uncertainties can theoretically be reduced in two ways: improved estimates of the surface values for current and temperature, and improved accuracy of the near-surface heights of dropsondes. Examples of the profiles, fluxes, and the above-mentioned problems will be presented.
mods:mods.note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Mark A. Bourassa, Professor Co-Directing Thesis; Heather M. Holbach, Professor Co-Directing Thesis; Robert E. Hart, Committee Member; Allison A. Wing, Committee Member.
